clusters.title: Israeli airstrike kills Houthi prime minister in Yemen, rebels say
clusters.neutral_headline: Israeli Airstrike Kills Houthi Prime Minister in Yemen

items.title: Israeli airstrike kills Houthi prime minister in Yemen, rebels say
items.standfirst: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...
items.content: Ahmed al-Rahawi killed alongside several ministers gathered for prerecorded speech by rebel group’s leaderAn Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the Houthi rebel-controlled government in Yemen’s capital, Sana’a, the Houthis have said.Ahmed al-Rahawi was killed in a strike in Sana’a on Thursday along with a number of ministers, the rebels said in a statement on Saturday. Other ministers and officials were wounded, the statement added without providing further details. Continue reading...

items.title: Yemen's Houthis confirm death of prime minister and other officials in Israeli strike
items.standfirst: The Iran-backed Houthis on Saturday confirmed that an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government and several other ministers in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, on Thursday.
items.content: The Iran-backed Houthis on Saturday confirmed that an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government and several other ministers in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa, on Thursday.

items.content: The Iranian-backed Houthis said an Israeli airstrike killed the prime minister of the rebel-controlled government in the Yemeni capital, Sanaa.(Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

items.title: Yemen’s Houthis confirm Israeli strike killed group’s prime minister
items.standfirst: Houthis say Ahmed al-Rahawi and a number of ministers were killed in Israel's attack on Sanaa this week.
items.content: Houthis say Ahmed al-Rahawi and a number of ministers were killed in Israel's attack on Sanaa this week.

ai_summary: An Israeli airstrike in Sana'a killed the Houthi prime minister, Ahmed al-Rahawi, on Thursday.
Several ministers from the Houthi-led government were also killed in the attack, according to reports.
The Houthis confirmed the death of al-Rahawi and other officials in a statement.
The Israeli military stated it struck a Houthi military target in the Sana'a area.
Other ministers and officials were wounded in the airstrike, the rebels said.

clusters.title: Investigation launched into ‘horrific murder’ of Ukrainian politician in Lviv
clusters.neutral_headline: Ukrainian Politician Andriy Parubiy Shot Dead in Lviv

items.title: Investigation launched into ‘horrific murder’ of Ukrainian politician in Lviv
items.standfirst: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...
items.content: Former parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy shot dead as EU ministers meet to discuss measures to force Moscow to the negotiating tableA Ukrainian former parliamentary speaker was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday, authorities said, as European foreign ministers met to discuss increasing pressure on Moscow to end its war against Ukraine.Andriy Parubiy, a member of parliament who served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019 and a key figure in Ukraine’s 2013 pro-European Maidan revolution, was shot dead, prosecutors said. A murder investigation has been launched and the president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, condemned the killing as a “horrific murder”. Continue reading...

items.content: President Zelensky said the killing of Parubiy was a "terrible murder" - with a manhunt under way.

items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemns killing of prominent politician Andriy Parubiy as 'horrendous murder'.

items.title: Ukrainian lawmaker shot dead in Lviv as Zelenskyy says hunt for killer is under way – as it happened
items.standfirst: This live blog is now closedAndriy Parubiy, a Ukrainian politician who previously served as the parliament speaker, has been shot dead in western city of Lviv, say officials.Confirming the news, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy wrote on X:Ukraine’s minister of internal affairs Ihor Klymenko and prosecutor general Ruslan Kravchenko have just reported the first known circumstances of the horrendous murder in Lviv. Andriy Parubiy was killed.My condolences to his family and loved ones. All necessary forces and means are engaged in the investigation and search for the killer. Continue reading...
items.content: This live blog is now closedAndriy Parubiy, a Ukrainian politician who previously served as the parliament speaker, has been shot dead in western city of Lviv, say officials.Confirming the news, Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy wrote on X:Ukraine’s minister of internal affairs Ihor Klymenko and prosecutor general Ruslan Kravchenko have just reported the first known circumstances of the horrendous murder in Lviv. Andriy Parubiy was killed.My condolences to his family and loved ones. All necessary forces and means are engaged in the investigation and search for the killer. Continue reading...

items.content: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy condemned Andriy Parubiy's killing as a "horrific murder" and said "all necessary forces and means" would be used in the investigation.

items.title: Russian strikes batter Ukraine as Zelenskyy accuses Putin of stalling peace talks
items.standfirst: Russia launched another massive attack across Ukraine as President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Moscow of dragging out peace negotiations.
items.content: Russia launched another massive attack across Ukraine as President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Moscow of dragging out peace negotiations.

items.title: Leading Ukrainian 'statesman' and 'patriot' assassinated in western Ukraine
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, 54, a leading figure in Ukraine’s pro-European protest movements who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the “horrific murder” of Andriy Parubiy, 54, a leading figure in Ukraine’s pro-European protest movements who was shot and killed in Lviv on Saturday. A former speaker of parliament, Parubiy also previously served as secretary of the National Security and Defence Council.

items.title: Lawmaker shot dead in Lviv as Russia launches ‘massive’ strikes across Ukraine
items.standfirst: Russia launched a "massive" overnight attack on central and southeastern Ukraine, killing one and wounding 26, officials said Saturday. Hours later, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced that a former parliamentary speaker had been shot dead in Lviv.
items.content: Russia launched a "massive" overnight attack on central and southeastern Ukraine, killing one and wounding 26, officials said Saturday. Hours later, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced that a former parliamentary speaker had been shot dead in Lviv.

ai_summary: Former Ukrainian parliamentary speaker Andriy Parubiy was shot dead in Lviv on Saturday.
Authorities have launched a murder investigation into the killing of Parubiy.
President Zelenskyy condemned the killing as a "horrific murder".
Parubiy served as parliamentary speaker from 2016 to 2019.
European foreign ministers met to discuss measures against Moscow.

items.content: A federal appeals court said many of the tariffs imposed by President Trump on dozens of countries earlier this year are not legally permissible, but didn't halt them.

items.title: US appeals court rules most of Trump's tariffs illegal under federal law
items.standfirst: A US appeals court found President Donald Trump exceeded his powers by invoking emergency authority to levy sweeping global tariffs, deeming most of them illegal but letting them stand until mid-October. Trump announced he would challenge the ruling at the Supreme Court. Shirli Sitbon tells us more.
items.content: A US appeals court found President Donald Trump exceeded his powers by invoking emergency authority to levy sweeping global tariffs, deeming most of them illegal but letting them stand until mid-October. Trump announced he would challenge the ruling at the Supreme Court. Shirli Sitbon tells us more.

items.title: Most of Trump’s tariffs are illegal, federal court rules
items.standfirst: US president found to have overstepped authority with tariff policies and accuses court of political biasDonald Trump overstepped his presidential powers with most of his globe-rattling tariff policies, a federal appeals court in Washington DC ruled on Friday.US law “bestows significant authority on the president to undertake a number of actions in response to a declared national emergency, but none of these actions explicitly include the power to impose tariffs, duties, or the like, or the power to tax”, the court said in the 7-4 ruling. Continue reading...
items.content: US president found to have overstepped authority with tariff policies and accuses court of political biasDonald Trump overstepped his presidential powers with most of his globe-rattling tariff policies, a federal appeals court in Washington DC ruled on Friday.US law “bestows significant authority on the president to undertake a number of actions in response to a declared national emergency, but none of these actions explicitly include the power to impose tariffs, duties, or the like, or the power to tax”, the court said in the 7-4 ruling. Continue reading...

items.content: Donald Trump's tariffs are unconstitutional, but they can remain in place for now, the US Court of Appeals has said.

ai_summary: A federal appeals court ruled Trump overstepped his authority on tariffs.
The court decision could impact the bond market.
The court found Trump's tariff policies were illegal.
The court did not halt the tariffs immediately.
The ruling could force Trump to refund tariff revenue.

items.title: US denies visas to Palestinian Authority leaders heading to UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, including Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Here’s General Secretary at the Palestinian National initiative, Mustafa Barghouti speech.
items.content: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, including Palestinian Authority president Mahmoud Abbas. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Here’s General Secretary at the Palestinian National initiative, Mustafa Barghouti speech.

items.title: US denies visas to Palestinian Authority leaders heading to UN General Assembly
items.standfirst: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, prompting France to urge Washington to allow full Palestinian participation. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.
items.content: The State Department said Friday that it would deny visas to members of the Palestinian Authority for next month’s UN General Assembly, prompting France to urge Washington to allow full Palestinian participation. Under an agreement as the host of UN headquarters in New York, the US is not supposed to refuse visas for officials heading to the world body. Washington Bureau Chief at The Guardian, David Smith, tells us more.

ai_summary: The United States denied visas to Palestinian Authority leaders.
The visa denials occurred before the UN General Assembly.
Turkey condemned the US for the visa cancellations.
The Palestinian Authority urged the US to reinstate the visas.
The US State Department confirmed the visa denials.

clusters.title: 3 dead after mob sets fire to Indonesian regional parliament building amid week of protests
clusters.neutral_headline: Protests Erupt in Indonesia After Deaths

items.title: 3 dead after mob sets fire to Indonesian regional parliament building amid week of protests
items.standfirst: Protests have erupted across Indonesia, sparked by reports of lawmakers receiving excessive housing allowances. The unrest intensified after the death of a 21-year-old ride-hailing driver during a rally in Jakarta on Thursday.
items.content: Protests have erupted across Indonesia, sparked by reports of lawmakers receiving excessive housing allowances. The unrest intensified after the death of a 21-year-old ride-hailing driver during a rally in Jakarta on Thursday.

items.title: Fire kills three people in Indonesia after protesters torch council buildings
items.standfirst: Cities in Indonesia rocked by protests after motorcycle taxi driver run over by police tactical vehicleProtesters have torched parliamentary buildings in three further Indonesian provinces, a day after at least three people were killed by a fire started by demonstrators at a council building in the city of Makassar.Protests erupted across Indonesia after footage spread showing a motorcycle taxi driver being run over and killed by a police vehicle on Thursday night during earlier demonstrations over low wages for workers and perks for lawmakers. Continue reading...

items.content: An angry mob set fire to a local parliament building in an Indonesian provincial capital, leaving at least three people dead and five others hospitalized, officials said.(Image credit: Masyudi Firmansyah)

items.title: Three killed in fire at Indonesian government building blamed on protesters
items.standfirst: At least three people were killed and several injured in a fire blamed on protesters in Sulawesi island.
items.content: At least three people were killed and several injured in a fire blamed on protesters in Sulawesi island.

items.title: Protests erupt in Indonesia over death of man hit by police vehicle
items.standfirst: Government faces calls for police reform amid violent clashes across Jakarta and demonstrations in other citiesHundreds of Indonesians have protested at sites across Jakarta over the death of a man hit by a police vehicle, in the first big test for Prabowo Subianto’s nearly year-old government.The man, a motorcycle ride-sharing driver, was hit at the site of violent clashes near parliament on Thursday as police sought to disperse demonstrators protesting about a number of issues including lawmakers’ pay and education funding. Continue reading...
items.content: Government faces calls for police reform amid violent clashes across Jakarta and demonstrations in other citiesHundreds of Indonesians have protested at sites across Jakarta over the death of a man hit by a police vehicle, in the first big test for Prabowo Subianto’s nearly year-old government.The man, a motorcycle ride-sharing driver, was hit at the site of violent clashes near parliament on Thursday as police sought to disperse demonstrators protesting about a number of issues including lawmakers’ pay and education funding. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Protests erupted across Indonesia after a motorcycle driver's death.
Protesters set fire to regional parliament buildings in multiple cities.
At least three people died in a fire at an Indonesian government building.
The government faces calls for police reform due to violent clashes.
The protests were sparked by reports of excessive housing allowances.

clusters.title: 3 Scottish brothers complete record-setting row across the Pacific Ocean
clusters.neutral_headline: Scottish Brothers Complete Pacific Ocean Row

items.title: 3 Scottish brothers complete record-setting row across the Pacific Ocean
items.standfirst: The trio from Edinburgh endured storms, seasickness, injuries and violent storms, while raising nearly $1 million for clean water projects.
items.content: The trio from Edinburgh endured storms, seasickness, injuries and violent storms, while raising nearly $1 million for clean water projects.

items.title: 139 days: 3 Scottish brothers set a record for fastest row across the Pacific
items.standfirst: Jamie, Ewan and Lachlan Maclean completed the fastest unsupported row across the Pacific, arriving in Cairns, Australia, on Saturday. They rowed over 9,000 miles non-stop from Peru.
items.content: Jamie, Ewan and Lachlan Maclean completed the fastest unsupported row across the Pacific, arriving in Cairns, Australia, on Saturday. They rowed over 9,000 miles non-stop from Peru.(Image credit: Nuno Avendano)

items.title: Brothers set new record for 9,000-mile Pacific row

items.content: Jamie, Ewan and Lachlan Maclean endured violent tropical storms during their 140-day journey.

items.title: Scottish brothers set new world record for 9,000-mile Pacific row
items.standfirst: Three brothers have set a new world for rowing across the Pacific Ocean unsupported in the fastest ever time.
items.content: Three brothers have set a new world for rowing across the Pacific Ocean unsupported in the fastest ever time.

ai_summary: Three Scottish brothers completed a record-setting row across the Pacific.
They rowed over 9,000 miles non-stop from Peru to Australia.
The brothers endured storms, injuries, and seasickness during the journey.
They completed the row in the fastest unsupported time.
The brothers raised nearly $1 million for clean water projects.

clusters.title: 8/29: The Takeout with Major Garrett
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Revokes Kamala Harris' Secret Service Protection

items.title: 8/29: The Takeout with Major Garrett
items.standfirst: Trump revokes Kamala Harris' Secret Service Protection; Ohio State begins title defense against Arch Manning & Texas Longhorns
items.content: Trump revokes Kamala Harris' Secret Service Protection; Ohio State begins title defense against Arch Manning & Texas Longhorns

items.title: Why has Kamala Harris' security detail been withdrawn?
items.standfirst: The overstretched Secret Service is required to provide 6 months of protection to former vice-presidents.
items.content: The overstretched Secret Service is required to provide 6 months of protection to former vice-presidents.

items.title: Trump revokes Harris’ security protections after Biden-issued extension
items.standfirst: The former vice president is set to start a book tour soon.
items.content: President Donald Trump discontinued former Vice President Kamala Harris’ Secret Service protection on Thursday, according to a memo reviewed by POLITICO. In a memo titled “Memorandum for the Secretary of Homeland Security,” and dated Aug. 28, Trump directed the Secret Service to revoke Harris’ security protections, effective Sept. 1. “You are hereby authorized to discontinue any security-related procedures previously authorized by Executive Memorandum, beyond those required by law, for the following individual effective September 1, 2025: Former Vice President Kamala D. Harris,” the memo read. The move, first disclosed by CNN, comes as Harris is set to embark on a 15-city tour to promote her new book, “107 Days,” starting next month. The tour will place the former vice president — who has remained largely out of the public eye since leaving office in January — back in the spotlight. “The Vice President is grateful to the United States Secret Service for their professionalism, dedication, and unwavering commitment to safety,” Harris spokesperson Kirsten Allen said in a statement. Former President Joe Biden had initially extended Harris’ Secret Service protection — which had been set to last until only mid-July — for an additional year, according to a person familiar with the move who was granted anonymity to discuss security arrangements. While presidents receive lifelong protection after leaving office, coverage for vice presidents typically lasts only six months after they leave office. A White House spokesperson confirmed protection has been revoked but did not comment further. Trump similarly ended extended security protections for Hunter Biden and his half-sister Ashley Biden earlier this year.

items.title: Donald Trump revokes Secret Service protection for Kamala Harris
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has revoked Secret Service protection for former vice president and 2024 Democratic rival Kamala Harris.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has revoked Secret Service protection for former vice president and 2024 Democratic rival Kamala Harris.

ai_summary: Donald Trump revoked Secret Service protection for Kamala Harris.
The Secret Service is required to provide six months of protection.
Harris is scheduled to begin a book tour soon.
Trump's decision comes amid political tensions.
The revocation was announced by Trump.

items.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy for 2nd time in less than a year
items.standfirst: The budget carrier filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process.
items.content: The budget carrier filed for fresh bankruptcy protection months after emerging from a Chapter 11 reorganization. The airline said it plans to keep flying as usual during the restructuring process.(Image credit: Charles Krupa)

items.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy protection for second time in a year
items.standfirst: Low-cost carrier experiences dwindling cash and mounting losses as recovery further hit by Trump tariffs US no-frills pioneer Spirit Airlines filed for fresh chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday, as dwindling cash and mounting losses derailed its turnaround efforts since emerging from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization in March.The carrier, recognizable by its bright yellow jets, has struggled to steady operations since emerging from its first bankruptcy in March. Flights, ticket sales, reservations and operations will continue, the airline said on Friday. Continue reading...
items.content: Low-cost carrier experiences dwindling cash and mounting losses as recovery further hit by Trump tariffs US no-frills pioneer Spirit Airlines filed for fresh chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday, as dwindling cash and mounting losses derailed its turnaround efforts since emerging from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization in March.The carrier, recognizable by its bright yellow jets, has struggled to steady operations since emerging from its first bankruptcy in March. Flights, ticket sales, reservations and operations will continue, the airline said on Friday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Spirit Airlines filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time.
The airline plans to continue flying during the restructuring process.
Spirit emerged from a previous Chapter 11 reorganization months ago.
The airline cited dwindling cash and mounting losses.
The flight attendants union warned to prepare for all scenarios.

clusters.title: Celebrity peer Lord Charles Brocket charged with rape

items.title: Celebrity peer Lord Charles Brocket charged with rape
items.standfirst: Peer who appeared on I’m a Celebrity denies charges of rape and sexual assault at Westminster magistrates courtA celebrity peer and former reality TV show contestant has appeared in court after being charged with rape and sexual assault by penetration, police said.Lord Charles Brocket, 73, a contestant on I’m a Celebrity … Get Me Out of Here!, appeared at Westminster magistrates court on Saturday. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.content: Lord Brockett was arrested on Friday, the Metropolitan Police said.

Brocket appeared in court and denied the charges.
The charges stem from an incident investigated by police.
Brocket is a celebrity peer and former reality TV contestant.
The Metropolitan Police arrested Brocket on Friday.

items.content: Kari Lake, acting CEO of the U.S. Agency for Global Media, announced the latest round of job cuts in a social media post late Friday.

items.title: Kari Lake lays off more than 500 staff at Voice of America parent agency
items.standfirst: Amid a contentious court battle, the Trump administration official sent long-awaited termination notices to staffers who have been waiting on administrative leave for months.
items.content: Amid a contentious court battle, the Trump administration official sent long-awaited termination notices to staffers who have been waiting on administrative leave for months.

ai_summary: The Trump administration cut over 500 jobs at Voice of America.
The job cuts were announced by Kari Lake.
Lake is the acting CEO of the U.S. Agency for Global Media.
The cuts come amid a contentious court battle.
Termination notices were sent to staff on administrative leave.

items.title: ‘We are on the streets’: Palestinians flee Israel’s assault on Gaza City
items.standfirst: Palestinian families are forced from their homes as Israel intensifies its deadly attacks in push to seize Gaza City.
items.content: Palestinian families are forced from their homes as Israel intensifies its deadly attacks in push to seize Gaza City.

items.title: Israel declares Gaza City a "combat zone": Death toll surpasses 63,000
items.standfirst: The Israeli military on Friday declared Gaza City a “dangerous combat zone” before a new offensive in the Palestinian enclave's largest city. Israel is moving forward with plans to seize Gaza City despite growing international pressure to end the nearly two-year conflict. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.
items.content: The Israeli military on Friday declared Gaza City a “dangerous combat zone” before a new offensive in the Palestinian enclave's largest city. Israel is moving forward with plans to seize Gaza City despite growing international pressure to end the nearly two-year conflict. France24 correspondent Noga Tarnopolsky reports the latest from Jerusalem.

The Israeli military is planning a new offensive in Gaza City.

items.title: What the Cracker Barrel backlash shows about Maga’s influence on US culture
items.standfirst: It was supposed to be a simple rebrand – or so Cracker Barrel thought. Earlier this month, the 56-year-old southern restaurant chain known for its country-store charm and nostalgic Americana aesthetic unveiled a new look: a minimalist logo, more modern interiors and a handful of new menu…

items.title: What the Cracker Barrel backlash shows about Maga’s influence on US culture
items.standfirst: What likely started as a routine refresh spiraled into a political storm that went all the way to the US presidentIt was supposed to be a simple rebrand – or so Cracker Barrel thought.Earlier this month, the 56-year-old southern restaurant chain known for its country-store charm and nostalgic Americana aesthetic unveiled a new look: a minimalist logo, more modern interiors and a handful of new menu items. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: Cracker Barrel faced backlash after a rebrand.
The rebrand included a new logo and menu items.
The backlash is seen as a political storm.
The controversy reached the US president.
The restaurant chain is known for its Americana aesthetic.

items.content: At least one person has been killed and 28 wounded, including children, in attack that targeted Zaporizhia.

items.content: Russia launched a major attack on Ukraine's capital in the early hours of Thursday evening, killing at least 19 people, including four children.

ai_summary: Russia launched a major attack on Ukraine.
The attack targeted 14 Ukrainian regions.
At least one person was killed in the attack.

At least 28 people were wounded, including children.

clusters.title: Opinion: It's time to 'move our feet'

items.title: Opinion: It's time to 'move our feet'
items.standfirst: The shooting this week at a Minneapolis Catholic school that killed 2 children won't the be last such incident. NPR's Scott Simon reflects on the cycle of school shootings and their aftermaths.
items.content: The shooting this week at a Minneapolis Catholic school that killed 2 children won't the be last such incident. NPR's Scott Simon reflects on the cycle of school shootings and their aftermaths.(Image credit: Bruce Kluckhohn)

items.title: Minneapolis school attacker 'obsessed with idea of killing children', officials say
items.standfirst: The two children killed in the shooting have been identified as Fletcher Merkel, eight, and Harper Moyski, 10.
items.content: The two children killed in the shooting have been identified as Fletcher Merkel, eight, and Harper Moyski, 10.

items.title: 'We love you, you will always be with us', says father of Minneapolis shooting victim
items.standfirst: Fletcher Merkel, 8, was one of two children killed in Wednesday's shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis.
items.content: Fletcher Merkel, 8, was one of two children killed in Wednesday's shooting at Annunciation Catholic School in Minneapolis.

ai_summary: A shooting at a Minneapolis Catholic school killed two children.
The victims were identified as Fletcher Merkel and Harper Moyski.
The shooter was reportedly obsessed with killing children.
The shooting is part of a cycle of school shootings.
The father of one victim shared a message of love.

clusters.title: European offer to delay sanctions on Iran still 'on the table'
clusters.neutral_headline: European offer to delay sanctions on Iran still 'on the table

items.title: European offer to delay sanctions on Iran still 'on the table'
items.standfirst: Britain, France, and Germany said their offer to extend the Iran nuclear deal and delay sanctions for 30 days “remains on the table”, said UK Ambassador Barbara Woodward at the UN Friday. The three nations triggered on Thursday the “snapback” mechanism to restore UN sanctions on Tehran for violating its 2015 nuclear commitments.
items.content: Britain, France, and Germany said their offer to extend the Iran nuclear deal and delay sanctions for 30 days “remains on the table”, said UK Ambassador Barbara Woodward at the UN Friday. The three nations triggered on Thursday the “snapback” mechanism to restore UN sanctions on Tehran for violating its 2015 nuclear commitments.

items.title: UK, France and Germany move to reimpose UN sanctions on Iran
items.standfirst: The three powers trigger a process which could restore sanctions in 30 days, calling Iran's nuclear programme a threat to peace and security.
items.content: The three powers trigger a process which could restore sanctions in 30 days, calling Iran's nuclear programme a threat to peace and security.

ai_summary: Britain, France, and Germany offered to delay Iran sanctions.
The offer is to extend the Iran nuclear deal for 30 days.
The three nations triggered the "snapback" mechanism.
The mechanism would restore UN sanctions on Tehran.
The sanctions are due to Iran violating nuclear commitments.

clusters.title: Court blocks Trump bid to end protections for 600,000 Venezuelans
clusters.neutral_headline: Court blocks Trump plan to end Venezuelan protections

items.title: Court blocks Trump bid to end protections for 600,000 Venezuelans
items.standfirst: Appellate panel upholds lower court’s ruling as homeland security spokesperson attacks ‘activist’ judgesA federal appeals court on Friday blocked Donald Trump’s plans to end protections for 600,000 people from Venezuela who have permission to live and work in the US, saying that plaintiffs are likely to win their claim that the president’s administration’s actions were unlawful.A three-judge panel of the ninth US circuit court of appeals unanimously upheld a lower court ruling that maintained temporary protected status for Venezuelans while TPS holders challenge actions by the Republican president’s administration in court. Continue reading...
items.content: Appellate panel upholds lower court’s ruling as homeland security spokesperson attacks ‘activist’ judgesA federal appeals court on Friday blocked Donald Trump’s plans to end protections for 600,000 people from Venezuela who have permission to live and work in the US, saying that plaintiffs are likely to win their claim that the president’s administration’s actions were unlawful.A three-judge panel of the ninth US circuit court of appeals unanimously upheld a lower court ruling that maintained temporary protected status for Venezuelans while TPS holders challenge actions by the Republican president’s administration in court. Continue reading...

items.title: Court blocks Trump from ending legal protections for 600,000 Venezuelans
items.standfirst: A federal appeals court has blocked the Trump administration's plans to end protections for 600,000 Venezuelans who have had permission to live and work in the U.S.
items.content: A federal appeals court has blocked the Trump administration's plans to end protections for 600,000 Venezuelans who have had permission to live and work in the U.S.

ai_summary: A federal appeals court blocked Trump's plan to end protections for 600,000 Venezuelans.
The court upheld a lower court ruling maintaining temporary protected status for Venezuelans.
Plaintiffs are likely to win their claim that the administration's actions were unlawful.
The court's decision prevents the termination of permission to live and work in the US.
A homeland security spokesperson attacked the judges involved in the ruling.

items.title: How a leaked phone call derailed the Thai PM's career - and the Shinawatra dynasty
items.standfirst: Thailand's Constitutional Court strikes again, removing yet another prime minister from office.
items.content: Thailand's Constitutional Court strikes again, removing yet another prime minister from office.

items.title: Thai prime minister sacked after leaked phone call
items.standfirst: Thailand's prime minister has been sacked after a leaked phone call with a senior Cambodian politician caused outrage.
items.content: Thailand's prime minister has been sacked after a leaked phone call with a senior Cambodian politician caused outrage.

ai_summary: Thailand's Constitutional Court removed the prime minister from office.
The removal followed a leaked phone call with a Cambodian politician.
The phone call caused significant public outrage in Thailand.
This is another instance of a prime minister being removed by the court.
The court's action is expected to cause political instability.
